title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.20 Part 1 | 22-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmilitam Yena Dasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale Shri Mate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from one verse, the 20th verse of the 16th chapter
of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, but since the purport is a big one, we will discuss
this verse in two different sessions.
So, this session we will be discussing part one, the first half of the purport of this
verse, as Prabhupada explains this elaborately, it is a very important verse.
So, the 20th verse Padair Nyunam Shochasi Maikapadam
Atmanam Vavrushalair Bhokshamanam Aaho Suradeen Hruta Yajna Bhaagaan
Praja Uthasvin Maghavatyavarshati
Further, here is a description.
Of the conditions in this Kalyuga of people in general, in various ways they suffer, in
so many ways.
Okay.
So, the meaning of this 20th verse is as follows, Dharma is speaking to Mother Earth, Dharma
in the form of a bull is speaking, addressing Mother Earth in the form of a cow.
So, what is Dharma telling the cow?
I have lost my three legs.
I have lost my three legs.
I have lost my three legs.
I have lost my three legs.
I have lost my four legs.
I have lost my five legs.
I have lost my five legs.
I have lost my six legs.
I have lost my seven legs.
So, if you have lost your six legs, you are now standing on one leg only.
Are you lamenting for my state of existence?
Or, are you in great anxiety because henceforward the unlawful meat eaters will exploit you?
Or, are you in a sorry plight because the demigods are now bereft of their share of
sacrificial offerings?
Because no sacrifices are being performed.
of being performed at present or are you grieving for living beings because of their sufferings
due to famine and drought. So different questions raised by Dharma are indicative of the different
ways people suffer in Kali Yuga due to this age. People suffer in so many ways. So very
elaborate purport written by Srila Prabhupada and we will go through this purport in two
different sessions. The first half of the purport I will read and we will discuss this.
In the purport Srila Prabhupada says, with the progress of the age of Kali, four things
particularly namely the duration of life, mercy, the power of recollection and moral
or religious principles will gradually diminish. Diminish means they will keep reducing, reducing,
reducing, reducing.
So the duration of life is reducing.
This is already explained in the beginning of the Bhagavatam that Kali Yuga people's maximum
duration of life is 100 years, about 100 years. Actually the Chastras say maximum duration
of life in Kali Yuga is 120 years, 120 years. That's how you hear sometimes in Japan somebody
is living whose 107 years, 110 years.
So the maximum duration of life in Kali Yuga is 120 years, which means that people in the
earlier ages called Satya Yuga, Tretha Yuga, Dwapar Yuga, they used to live a longer life
span. And that is described in the Bhagavatam. What is the life span of people in earlier
ages? In Dwapar Yuga, people used to live an average of 1000 years. That is the duration
of life. So 20 years is equivalent to 10 times more than that in Kali Yuga approximately.
